date: stated on September 18, 2014 in a TV ad:
title: Mary Burke is unequivocally supporting Obama's care and wants to expand it, as Scott Walker says.
text: (Joff) The Scott Walker campaign released one of the sinister television advertisements on 18 September 2014. The announcement opens with fire on the screen and weeps the alarms in the background as a whistle with a deep voice: "I've been called the lie of the year." The reference is to the 2013 National Polyte Vac lie, which President Barack Obama used to say about the affordable Care Act: "If you like your health care plan, you can keep it." "But while millions of doctors have lost their plans, Mary Burke says that she continues to support Obama's care programme unequivocally and wants to expand it." We'll check Walker's claim about Burke -- she says she supports the law "undisputably" and she wants to expand it. Of course, the Affordable Care Act is the signed Obama Act. Among its many provisions, the Health Care Reform Act provides for people to have health insurance, through an employer or a government programme or to purchase it through a government subsidy through an electronic market established as part of the Act. The Act also provides for the expansion of the Medicaid programme, the health-care programme for the poor run by the Federal Government and the states, by making millions more low-income people eligible to benefit from it. But Walker refused to expand in Wisconsin, saying he didn't trust the federal government to keep its promise to bear the vast majority of the costs. Obama has been in law since March 2010, but its provisions have entered into force in stages. One milestone took place on 1 October 2013 when electronic markets opened.
